Plicae circulares (circular folds) – aka valves of Kerckring: permanent transverse folds of mucosa with submucosal connective tissue core; extend halfway to two-thirds around circumference of lumen; function to slow movement of chyme & increase surface area.

Original: Fig 14.16 from Young & Heath, Wheater's Functional Histology, 4th ed. (2000), p262
[H1] How to get the most out of your intestine.
Start with a long tube
Convolute the absorptive surface of the tube
Add enzymes that break down luminal contents
Keep the tube moving, mix contents
[H1] Enzymes/bile digest luminal contents:.
"Chyme" enters from stomach, stimulates intestinal enteroendocrine cells in intestine to secrete:
[LIST_ITEM] Secretin → pancreatic secretion
[LIST_ITEM] CCK (cholecystokinin) → pancreatic secretion → gall bladder contraction
Ampulla of Vater: intestinal segment of the common duct that delivers secretions to duodenum
[LIST_ITEM] from pancreas (trypsin, chymotrypsin, amylase, lipase)
[LIST_ITEM] from liver via gall bladder (bile-emulsifies fat)
Enzymes in small intestinal absorptive cell (enterocyte) membrane complete the process of digestion and absorb the breakdown products
Secreted as inactive forms, activated by enterokinase cleavage (enterokinase produced in duodenum)
[H1] Enzymes/bile digest luminal contents: activation of zymogens via enterokinase/trypsin.

[H1] Epithelial cell types: Small intestine.
Enterocytes (majority of cells): Absorption (and secretion, e.g. enterokinase)
Goblet Cells: Increase in number as you descend the GI tract. Produce acid glycoproteins (mucins). Lubrication. Stain with Alcian Blue or PAS.
Enteroendocrine cells: Part of the “diffuse neuroendocrine system”. Produce CCK, glucagon, secretin, motilin, etc. Hormone secretion.
Paneth cells: Located at base of crypts. Exocrine cells. Secrete lysozyme and $\alpha$-defensins; Antibacterial activity.
[H1] Villus tip.
Ly = Lymphocyte P = Plasma cell M = Muscle C = Capillary

[H1] GALT: Gut Associated Lymphoid Tissue.
(approximately 1/4 of mucosa)
[LIST_ITEM] Plasma cells, macrophages, lymphocytes located in lamina propria and submucosa
[LIST_ITEM] Also “intraepithelial” lymphocytes – specialized T cells found between columnar epithelial cells
[LIST_ITEM] Lymph nodules (or follicles): aggregations of lymphocytes usually in lamina propria, sometimes extending into submucosa
[LIST_ITEM] activated leukocytes go to nearby lymph nodes, activate T+B cells, which “home” to GI mucosa.

[LIST_ITEM] plasma cells develop from activated B cells in follicles and migrate into lamina propria to secrete antibodies (secretory IgA, which can be selectively transported across enterocytes into the gut lumen)
[LIST_ITEM] “Peyer’s patches:” large aggregates of nodules (technically this term applies to aggregates found in ileum)
[LIST_ITEM] covered by M cells (specialized for uptake & presentation of antigen to underlying macrophages and lymphoid cells)
Similar large aggregates also found in the APPENDIX
[H1] Peyer's patch histology - TEM.
JOURNAL
Junquiera and Carneiro. Basic Histology, 10th ed. (2003), p317 Fig 15-31
[H1] Sprue: Immune reactivity to gliadin (a protein in most wheat cereals). Pathology primarily in jejunum. Diagnostic biopsy.

Outer longitudinal muscle: three discontinuous bands (Teniae coli, TC)
Semilunal folds (arrows) caused by contraction of TC
Sacculations of external surface = Haustra coli (HC)
Small fatty projections of the serosa = omental appendices (OA)
IPO-EREL
Ross and Pawlina, Histology: A Text and Atlas, 5th ed. (2006), p548.
[H1] Colon.
Flat epithelium (no villi)
Thick muscularis mucosae
Thick inner circular muscle
Three bands of longitudinal muscle (discontinuous) = teniae coli
Two types of muscle contraction by muscularis externa: Segmentation: local contraction, mixes contents Peristalsis: moves feces down the tube

[H1] Susceptibility to disease is regional in the small and large intestine.
Predominant location of pathology:
[LIST_ITEM] Sprue - jejunum
[LIST_ITEM] Crohn's disease - ileum
[LIST_ITEM] Ulcerative colitis - colon/rectum
[LIST_ITEM] Hirschsprung's disease - colon
[LIST_ITEM] Bacterial colitis - SI and/or LI
Cancer is a disease of the large bowel and is rarely seen in the small intestine
[H1] Recto-Anal junction.
sebaceous gland

[LIST_ITEM] Internal and external anal sphincters: smooth and skeletal m., respectively
[LIST_ITEM] Note also dermal sebaceous glands and adipose tissue in wall of anal canal

[H1] Learning Objectives.

[LIST_ITEM] Be able to identify and describe the function of the layers AND COMPONENT CELLS/TISSUES in the wall of the digestive tract (mucosa, submucosa, muscularis externa and adventitia/serosa), and be aware of how the layers may differ in the small and large intestine.
[LIST_ITEM] Be able to identify and know the general functions of the following regions of the GI tract:
[LIST_ITEM] Duodenum
[LIST_ITEM] Jejunum/ileum
[LIST_ITEM] Colon
[LIST_ITEM] Appendix
[LIST_ITEM] Rectum
[LIST_ITEM] Anal canal
